resources.string: In the previous examples, we have used when() for adding behavior to the mocks. But this way won’t work for methods that return void. If we try to use when() with a void method, the IDE will mark an error, and it won’t let us compile the code. First, we are going to change the previous example to make AuthenticatorInterface method return void, and make it throw an exception if the user has not been successfully authenticated, to give sense to the void return. We are going to create another package com.javacodegeeks.mockitotutorial.voidmethod, not to modify the previous working code.
